name: Simple Present Tense
explanation: The Simple Present is used for habits, universal truths, and repeated actions. In exams, watch third-person singular errors (he/she/it + s/es).
structure: Subject + base verb (add s/es for third person singular)
keyPoints: Used for facts and general truths
examples: The sun rises in the east.

questions.question: Simple Present is NOT used for:

name: Present Continuous Tense
explanation: Used for actions happening right now or temporary actions. Exams test confusion between simple present and continuous.

incorrect.explanation: Stative verbs like 'know' are not used in continuous form.

questions.question: They ____ football at the moment.
questions.explanation: At the moment indicates ongoing action.

name: Simple Past Tense
explanation: Used for completed actions in the past. Competitive exams test irregular verbs and wrong past forms.
keyPoints: Time indicators: yesterday, ago, last night

questions.question: Choose correct sentence:
questions.explanation: Past form of go is went.

name: Simple Future (Will)
explanation: Used for decisions made at the moment, promises, predictions. Exams trap: avoid 'will' in time clauses.

incorrect.sentence: I will call you when he will come.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: I will go when he will arrive.

name: Basic Subject-Verb Agreement
explanation: A singular subject takes a singular verb. A plural subject takes a plural verb. Exams test collective nouns and confusing phrases.
keyPoints: Ignore words between subject and verb

questions.question: The list of items ____ on the table.

name: Personal Pronouns
explanation: Pronouns replace nouns. Exams test subject vs object forms (I/me, he/him).

name: Use of A and An
explanation: Use 'a' before consonant sounds and 'an' before vowel sounds. Exams test sound, not spelling.
structure: a + consonant sound | an + vowel sound

name: Use of The
explanation: 'The' is used for specific nouns, unique things, superlatives, and known references.
examples: The book you gave me is good.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: She bought the pen yesterday (first mention).

name: Prepositions of Time (At, On, In)
explanation: Use 'at' for exact time, 'on' for days/dates, and 'in' for months, years, long periods. Exams frequently test this.

name: Coordinating Conjunctions (FANBOYS)
explanation: Coordinating conjunctions join equal clauses. Remember FANBOYS: For, And, Nor, But, Or, Yet, So.
keyPoints: Comma before conjunction in compound sentence
Common exam trap: misuse of 'but' and 'so'
examples: I tried hard, but I failed.
He was tired, so he slept.

questions.question: Choose correct:
options: I was tired, but I worked.
I was tired but I worked.
I was tired and but worked.

questions.question: FANBOYS stands for:
options: For And Nor But Or Yet So
For All New Big Old Young Small

name: Modal Verb: Can
explanation: 'Can' expresses ability, permission, or possibility. Exams test confusion between can and may for permission.

incorrect.explanation: Modal verbs are followed by base verb without 'to'.

name: Modal Verb: Must
explanation: 'Must' expresses obligation or strong necessity. Exams test confusion between must and have to.

name: Comparative Adjectives
explanation: Comparatives compare two things. Add -er or use 'more' for longer adjectives. Exams test irregular forms.

incorrect.sentence: She is more taller than me.

questions.question: Choose correct:
options: He is more taller than me.

questions.question: Identify error:
questions.explanation: Do not use 'more' with short adjective.

questions.question: This exam is ____ than the last one.

name: Superlative Adjectives
explanation: Superlatives compare three or more things. Add -est or use 'most'. Exams test article 'the' before superlatives.
examples: This is the most interesting book.

questions.question: This is ____ movie I have seen.

name: Adverbs of Frequency
explanation: Adverbs of frequency show how often something happens. Exams test placement before main verb but after 'be'.

incorrect.explanation: Adverb should come before main verb.

name: Prepositions of Place (In, On, At)
explanation: Use 'in' for enclosed spaces, 'on' for surfaces, and 'at' for specific points. Exams test confusion between in/on for locations.
examples: The book is on the table.
He is at the bus stop.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: The bag is on the chair.

name: Subordinating Conjunctions (Because, Although, If)
explanation: Subordinating conjunctions join dependent clauses to main clauses. Exams test comma placement and clause order.
examples: I stayed home because it was raining.
Although he was tired, he worked.
If you try, you will succeed.

questions.question: Choose correct:
options: Although he was tired, he finished.

questions.question: Correct structure:
options: Although he was tired he worked.
Although he was tired, he worked.
He worked although he was tired.

questions.question: If you hurry, you ____ catch the train.

name: Possessive Pronouns
explanation: Possessive pronouns show ownership. Exams test confusion between possessive adjectives and pronouns.
structure: Mine, yours, his, hers, ours, theirs

incorrect.sentence: This is her book is her's.

name: There is / There are
explanation: Use 'there is' for singular nouns and 'there are' for plural nouns. Exams test agreement with nearest noun.

name: Use of Capital Letters
explanation: Capital letters are used at the beginning of sentences, proper nouns, days, months, and nationalities. Exams test lowercase errors.
structure: Capital letter at start and proper nouns

questions.question: Capital letters are NOT used for:

name: Present Perfect Tense
explanation: Used for actions completed at an unspecified time or with present relevance. Exams test confusion between past simple and present perfect.
keyPoints: Do not use specific past time

incorrect.explanation: Do not use specific past time with present perfect.

name: Past Continuous Tense
explanation: Used for actions ongoing at a specific time in the past. Exams test interruption cases (when/while).

name: Either...Or / Neither...Nor
explanation: With 'either...or' and 'neither...nor', the verb agrees with the nearest subject. Exams frequently test this rule.
structure: Either A or B + verb (agree with nearest subject)
examples: Either John or his friends are coming.
Neither the boys nor the teacher is here.
Either she or I am responsible.

incorrect.sentence: Neither the boys nor the teacher are here.

questions.question: Either he or his friends ____ coming.
Identify error:
options: Either she or I am ready.
Neither he nor they are late.
Either boys or teacher are present.
Neither boys nor teacher is present.

questions.question: Neither the teacher nor the students ____ ready.

name: Adverbs of Manner
explanation: Adverbs of manner describe how an action happens. Often formed by adding -ly to adjectives.

name: Use of Comma in Lists
explanation: Use commas to separate items in a list. Exams test missing comma errors.
examples: I bought apples, oranges, and bananas.
She likes tea, coffee, and milk.
They invited Ram, Ravi, and Sita.

incorrect.sentence: I bought apples oranges and bananas.

questions.question: Choose correct:
options: I bought apples, oranges, and bananas.
I bought apples oranges and bananas.
I bought apples oranges, and bananas.
I bought apples, oranges and bananas,

questions.question: Identify error:
options: She likes tea, coffee and milk.
He bought pen, pencil, and eraser.
They invited Ram Ravi and Sita.
We saw cats, dogs, and birds.

name: Modal Verb: May
explanation: 'May' expresses permission (formal) or possibility. Exams test difference between can and may.

incorrect.explanation: Modal verbs take base verb without 'to'.

name: Reflexive Pronouns
explanation: Reflexive pronouns are used when subject and object are same. Exams test unnecessary use.
structure: myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, themselves

name: Order of Adjectives
explanation: Adjectives follow a specific order: Opinion, Size, Age, Shape, Color, Origin, Material, Purpose (OSASCOMP). Exams test wrong order.
structure: Opinion → Size → Age → Shape → Color → Origin → Material → Purpose

name: Prepositions of Direction (To, Into, Onto)
explanation: 'To' shows movement toward a place. 'Into' shows movement inside. 'Onto' shows movement to surface.
examples: The cat jumped onto the table.

incorrect.sentence: He walked to the room (entering meaning).

name: Countable and Uncountable Nouns
explanation: Countable nouns can be counted (books). Uncountable nouns cannot (water, information). Exams test wrong plural forms.

name: Future with Going To
explanation: Used for planned future actions or strong predictions based on evidence. Exams test confusion with 'will'.
structure: Subject + am/is/are + going to + base verb
examples: I am going to study tonight.

name: Modal Verb: Should
explanation: 'Should' expresses advice or mild obligation. Exams test difference between should and must.

name: Demonstrative Pronouns
explanation: This/That (singular), These/Those (plural). Exams test singular-plural agreement.

name: Adverbs of Time
explanation: Adverbs of time tell when something happens (yesterday, today, tomorrow). Exams test tense consistency.

name: Use of Question Mark
explanation: A question mark is used at the end of direct questions. Exams test missing punctuation.

questions.question: He asked, "Are you ready?" – punctuation is:
